components.name: AppComponent
components.templateData:
Perceptual Contrast

Main Color Controls

Color Metadata

Options

Notes

Object: A readout that shows two different values, a number in pixels that the current contrast level supports, and 'invisible' when the current contrast level is too low to support any object.

Perceptual contrast: Score that better gauges contrast than WCAG 2 in the creation of inclusive visual designs. For more information on the value used for Perceptual Contrast, refer to Myndex article Why APCA?

WCAG 2 compatible: A score compatible with use for WCAG 2.x success criteria. This score meets or exceeds WCAG 2 scores to better include those with atypical vision.

WCAG 2: Scores that are included for reference onlydo not use this score for judging Accessible Contrast.

Display WCAG 2 compatible value: Option that swaps out perceptual contrast score visually displayed at top of the app. Screen reader users can access the same value regardless of this option in the Differences table located in the Color Metadata section.

Constant chroma: Option that forces the color sliders to limit light and dark variation of colors to tints and shades that have the same chroma and hue of the inputted color maintaining the objective identity of your input color.

Contact Information and Feedback

Made by pawn002, who would appreciate bug reports and feature requests for this app to help improve its Accessibility.

import { Component, Input, Output, EventEmitter } from '@angular/core'; import type { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-header', template: `

Acme

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!
`, styleUrls: ['./header.css'], }) export default class HeaderComponent { @Input() user: User | null = null; @Output() onLogin = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onLogout = new EventEmitter(); @Output() onCreateAccount = new EventEmitter(); }

components.name: PageComponent
components.template:
Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
components.sourceCode:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import type { User } from './User'; @Component({ selector: 'storybook-page', template: `

Pages in Storybook

We recommend building UIs with a component-driven process starting with atomic components and ending with pages.

Render pages with mock data. This makes it easy to build and review page states without needing to navigate to them in your app. Here are some handy patterns for managing page data in Storybook:

  • Use a higher-level connected component. Storybook helps you compose such data from the "args" of child component stories
  • Assemble data in the page component from your services. You can mock these services out using Storybook.

Get a guided tutorial on component-driven development at Storybook tutorials . Read more in the docs .

Tip Adjust the width of the canvas with the Viewports addon in the toolbar
`, styleUrls: ['./page.css'], }) export default class PageComponent { user: User | null = null; doLogout() { this.user = null; } doLogin() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } doCreateAccount() { this.user = { name: 'Jane Doe' }; } }
